titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the Taconic Foundation records FA407
titlestmt.author: Mary Ann Quinn

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-09-12 15:19:42 -0400.

physdesc.extent: 206 document boxes, 2 standard records boxes, 3 oversized flat boxes, and 2 card files

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Taconic Foundation records are arranged into four series: Series 1 - Grants; Series 2 - Board Materials; Series 3 - Organization Records; Series 4 - Tax Records.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Philanthropists Stephen R. Currier and his wife Audrey Bruce Currier established the Taconic Foundation in 1958.

Stephen Richard Currier, born in Santa Fe, New Mexico, in 1930, was the son of Richard and Mary Prue Currier. His father, who was descended from the family of the lithographer Nathaniel Currier, was a painter. Currier's parents divorced in 1936. His mother, an editor for Vogue magazine, married the prominent arts patron Edward M. M. Warburg in 1939. Stephen Currier was educated at St. Bernard's School and Horace Mann–Lincoln School in New York and the George School in Bucks County, Pennsylvania. He enrolled at Harvard in 1948.

Audrey Bruce Currier, born in 1933 to the diplomat David Bruce and his wife Ailsa Mellon Bruce, was the first grandchild of Andrew W. Mellon. The Bruces separated in the early 1940s and divorced in 1945. Audrey attended the Brearley School and the Foxcroft School, and enrolled at Radcliffe in 1952, from which she graduated in 1956.

Audrey and Stephen met while students at Harvard and Radcliffe and married in November 1955. After Audrey's graduation, they settled in New York. They had three children: Andrea Bruce Currier, Lavinia McClendon Currier, and Michael Stephen Currier.

Audrey and Stephen both hailed from wealthy families, and they received a steady flow of income from the Mellon family trust. Private and personally reticent (Audrey, in particular, was extremely shy), they created the Taconic Foundation in 1958 with a goal of channeling their giving toward areas neglected by other foundations and where they could have the greatest impact. Creating equality of opportunity — in education, housing, employment, and civil rights — became the new foundation's enduring mission. The foundation initially limited its grantmaking to the New York City area and New England, where it focused particularly on issues of child welfare and mental illness. The focus soon evolved into a broader concern with race relations, legal reform, and civil rights. Stephen Currier became a crucial mediator between the Federal government and civil rights leaders. The Taconic Foundation was instrumental in bringing civil rights organizations together in support of the Voter Education Project, and through the foundation Steven Currier launched the Potomac Institute and Urban America to bring attention and research to bear on problems of racial justice, equal opportunity, and the urban crisis.

In January 1967, Audrey and Stephen Currier perished when their plane disappeared in the Caribbean. John G. Simon, president of the Taconic Foundation, and his wife Claire, good friends of the Curriers, took guardianship of the Currier children.

The Taconic Foundation continued on course for some forty-five years after the Curriers' disappearance, closing up in 2013. Equality of opportunity remained its central priority, even as its program areas evolved to focus on issues of housing rights and affordable housing, community and economic development, and youth employment.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Rockefeller Archive Center holds title, copyright, and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them, and has authority to grant permission to cite and publish archival material from the collection.

Researchers who visit the Rockefeller Archive Center are granted permission to examine archival material. Permission to cite, quote from, or publish material from the Center's collections must be requested separately by writing. See Archivists for details.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Brittle or damaged items, or materials otherwise in need of preservation care, may be closed to researchers at the discretion of the RAC Head of Archival Services/Head of Reference.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Level 3, Standard Processing. Material is housed in acid-free boxes and folders.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Taconic Foundation donated its records to the Rockefeller Archive Center by deed of gift dated May 31, 2012.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Special Formats (digital media, library materials, oversize, and photographic material) have been separated from the body of the collection. All pertinent items are assigned a unique separation number, as noted. Requests to access open special formats should reference the unique separation number.

appraisal.head: Appraisal
appraisal.p: Duplicate copies of publications, reports, and board materials have been removed during processing and discarded.

A series of business records, consisting mainly of various office files from 1996-1997, was judged non-archival and discarded in processing. The 2.8 cubic feet of records included bank and investment statements, a bond-account ledger volume, payroll records, pension-account statements, and various accounting and transaction records. The records pertained to routine financial transactions and investment performance during a limited period, and they shed no particular light on the foundation's history, mission, or grantmaking. A large portion of the material included confidential information on salary payments and would have been restricted were it retained.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Taconic Foundation was in its own words, "a fairly small foundation trying to address some very big problems." Founded in 1958 by philanthropists Stephen and Audrey Currier, the Taconic Foundation worked consistently during its fifty-five-year existence to combat social inequities and promote equality of opportunity. Under Stephen Currier's lead, Taconic was at the forefront in organizing support for the civil rights movement and seeking solutions to the urban crisis. Initial program areas focused on race relations, mental health, and child development. Later programs evolved to focus on families and youth, educational innovation, community organizing, housing and neighborhood development, and youth employment.

Along with supporting research into particular issues, the Foundation led by funding demonstration projects or "model" programs, such as its youth employment programs. When necessary — as in its fight against red-lining or exclusionary zoning practices — the Taconic Foundation did not shy away from funding legal remedies, supporting litigation and monitoring to ensure compliance with the law. Taconic also helped pioneer the concept of "program-related investments" as a source of capital for minority or low-income neighborhoods. From its early days, the Taconic Foundation targeted problems, devised solutions, and engaged others, including the government, to follow suit.

The Taconic Foundation enjoyed remarkable continuity in its membership and governance from its founding to its final closure in 2013, and many trustees served for life. When incorporated in May 1958, the Taconic Foundation board consisted of Stephen R. Currier, chair; Audrey Bruce Currier, and Lloyd K. Garrison. Jane Lee Eddy joined the same year as executive secretary, retiring (as executive director) only in 1997, when the foundation transferred responsibility for its administration to J.P. Morgan (she continued to serve as trustee). Child psychologist Edith Entenman and attorney and professor John G. Simon joined the board in 1959. After the Curriers' death in 1967, John Simon presided over the foundation for the remainder of its existence. In 1960, the board elected Dorothy Hirshon as a trustee, and in 1961 added Harold C. Fleming, executive director of the Potomac Institute. Other trustees included: Vernon Jordan (served 1976–1992), Alan J. Dworsky (1980– 2013), Michael Currier (1984–1987), Susan Curnan (1987–circa 1994), Melvin Mister (1989–circa 2012), L. F. Boker Doyle (1989–2013), Bill Green (1993–2002), Hildy Simmons (2000–2013), Oliver W. Wesson (2000–2013), and Veronica White (2004–2010).

As the Taconic Foundation marked its fiftieth anniversary in 2008, the board considered its history and planned its legacy. It commissioned historical timelines, program reviews, and oral history interviews to document the foundation's accomplishments. The process of Quo Vadimus (Where are we going?) reflection, first begun in the mid-1990s but ever present as the board acknowledged its limited resources and the impending retirement of its long-term officers, turned to a wide-ranging consideration of how to close a foundation. The resulting spend-down endowed a program of Taconic Fellows at three of the foundation's long-term grantee organizations, made final grants to other significant grantees, and awarded several smaller grants to organizations chosen by each of the trustees.

In a coda to its spend-down, at its final meeting of March 28, 2013, the Taconic Foundation board transferred leadership to the grandchildren of Stephen and Audrey Currier, who assumed the mantle of a reborn and newly named Taconic Foundation for Social Justice.

The Taconic Foundation records document the foundation's board deliberations and grantmaking from its founding in 1958 to its closure in 2013. Significant program areas include race relations, voting rights, urban renewal, housing rights, neighborhood preservation and economic development, school reform, mental health, child welfare, and youth employment. Organizations funded, and in some cases established, by the Taconic Foundation include the Cooperative Assistance Fund, the Voter Education Project, the Southern Regional Council, the Potomac Institute, the Suburban Action Institute, and Urban America. While the foundation's projects particularly targeted problems in New York City neighborhoods, it also worked on behalf of race relations in the South and of housing reform in Chicago, Philadelphia, and other metropolitan and suburban areas. The Smokey House Center, developed on the Curriers' property in Danby, Vermont, provided the Taconic Foundation with a model for its youth employment training program.

While Stephen Currier was widely credited for his civil rights leadership, there is very little documentation of his personal activism in the Taconic Foundation records, and the collection contains no record of his work with the Council on United Civil Rights Leadership. A letter from Jane Lee Eddy to Dorothy Height (March 9, 1991, in box 56, folder 579), indicates that "those records were part of the Curriers' personal files and were separated from Taconic materials after their death." The Curriers' personal papers remain in the possession of the family.

Around October 1988, the Taconic Foundation donated "seven boxes of material relating to the civil rights movement" to the New York Public Library's Schomburg Center, and some forty-nine books to the Municipal Reference and Research Center of the City of New York. Presumably, the Schomburg donation also consisted of books, but we have not been able to confirm this fact.

The Taconic Foundation records are comprised of paper and digital records, integrated in one arrangement and description. Records include correspondence, memos, reports, publications, and photographs. Digital records are in standard file formats for documents, spreadsheets, and presentations (mainly .doc, .xls, .ppt, and PDFs). While there may be some duplication between the paper and digital components of hybrid files, there is no exact correspondence between the two formats, and the file contents do not necessarily coincide.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

physdesc.extent: 172 document boxes (including 1 half-box), 2 oversized flat boxes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Grants series documents the Taconic Foundation's grantmaking from its inception in the late 1950s and early 1960s up to, but generally not including, its final grant cycles and spend-down in 2008-2012. Records concerning these latter grants are found, for the most part, not in the Grants series, but in the Organization Records series, under "Grantmaking and Foundation History" or under "Spend-Down Process." These late grants are grouped collectively rather than by individual grantee.

Grant files contain proposals, correspondence, and reports, and sometimes publications or literature relating to the institution or the particular grant. Most grant files also include one or more grant memos, which Taconic Foundation officers wrote for each new grant or renewal, setting forth for the board the terms of the request, the nature of the organization and its history with Taconic, previous funding, the pros and cons of the proposed grant, its fit with the Taconic program, and the recommended action.

The Taconic Foundation also funded a number of "Projects" that produced research and reports on issues of concern to the foundation or that resulted in the creation of new organizations that then benefited from Taconic grant support. Projects included, for example, the Assessment Project on Negro Needs, Davidoff's and Gold's proposals for low-income housing in lower Manhattan, the Voter Education Project, the Smokey House Project, and the Cooperative Assistance Fund.

A number of simple correspondence files are interspersed in this grants series. Each of these files generally contains just a few pieces of correspondence. While some correspondents have connections to Taconic projects, for the most part the correspondence files seem to be remnants of either a finite correspondence or a larger series. There is no general correspondence series in the Taconic records, and the Grants series constitutes the main series of files.

The Grants series is fairly comprehensive, but it is not a complete set of grant files. Some significant reports, such as Mary Conway Kohler's study of Youth and Work in New York, are not found in the files. Records are sparse or sometimes lacking for some of the Taconic Foundation's early grants. Many of the early programs were first launched with personal grants from the Curriers before the Taconic Foundation assumed their funding, and these hybrid origins may, perhaps, account for some of the gaps.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: In some of the later grant files (from around 2000-2007), narrative reports and supporting material such as financial reports or publications were arranged separately from correspondence documenting the grant decisions. In most cases we have reintegrated the material into a general chronological run. In cases where we have preserved the division, we have labeled the folders of supporting material "Literature" and/or "Reports." These folders may also include the covering correspondence.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Grants series is arranged alphabetically by name of institution or subject.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: For earlier materials on the Open Doors program see Public Education Association.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Open Doors program established a partnership between schools and businesses, to introduce students to occupational choices and facilitate the transition from school to work. Open Doors was at first jointly sponsored by the Public Education Association and the New York Urban Coalition, and then from 1970 up to 1974 solely by the Public Education Association. The Economic Development Council assumed sponsorship in 1974.
In November 1978, the Taconic Foundation commissioned an evaluation of the Open Doors program.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Support for School-Business Partnership project, under the direction of Frances (Mrs. Robert) Low.

The Open Doors program established a partnership between schools and businesses, to introduce students to occupational choices and facilitate the transition from school to work. Frances Low received project funding from the Taconic Foundation in 1968-1969 to investigate and report on training and counseling programs in the New York City Public Schools and on methods of relating local business organizations to the schools. Open Doors was at first jointly sponsored by the Public Education Association and the New York Urban Coalition, and then from 1970 up to 1974 solely by the Public Education Association. The Economic Development Council assumed sponsorship in 1974. For later material, see files on Economic Development Council of New York City: Open Doors.

did.unittitle: Regional Plan Association: Gateway Citizens Committee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Established in June 1970, the Gateway Citizens Committee advocated on behalf of Gateway National Recreation Area as an urban national park and worked to ensure the protection and preservation of the lands surrounding New York Harbor. The Gateway project was one of the Taconic Foundation's longest-running grants.
For the origins and early funding of the Gateway project, see the file for Regional Plan Association: Breezy Point. For later materials see also Regional Plan Association: Friends of Gateway.
Files for 1986-1988 include materials relating to the Friends of Gateway and to the Regional Plan Association's Open Space and Transit on Track projects.

Later materials for 1988-1989 (pertaining mainly to the Bridging the Social Chasm program) and for 1996-1997 (pertaining to the Workforce and Community Development project) have been separated and are refiled under Regional Plan Association: General Program.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The board was variously described as Board of Directors or Board of Trustees. From the time of the board's founding until its administrative transition to J.P. Morgan & Co. in 1997, it is described in the records as the Board of Directors. Starting in 1997 and continuing until 2007, the records refer to the Board of Trustees. From 2008 on, the board is again called the Board of Directors.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Board Materials consist of Minutes, Meeting Materials (Meetings), and related Board Memoranda.
The Meetings files have been grouped into two sets, reflecting variations in their contents and arrangement, but combined they form a coherent chronological run of files.
There are no Meeting Materials or Memoranda files for the period 1958-1973 or for the period 1992-1996, but the Minutes files document Board decisions during these years.

The series includes both paper and digital records. While there may be some duplication between the two formats, there is no exact correspondence between the paper and digital components of hybrid files, and the file contents do not necessarily coincide.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: There are no minutes in these files for the years 1978, 1980-1981, and 1983. For the period 2000-2012, minutes in this set of files exist in electronic form only.
Minutes for 2000-2004 and some other years may also be found among the Meeting Materials files.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The 1997–2012 Meetings files combine material from three sets of paper files, plus a set of electronic records.

The overlapping sets of paper files require some explanation. For the period May 1998–April 2006, there were two sets of board meeting files, which we have integrated in processing. One series appears to have been Lisa Philp's files (starting in September 1998), as it includes her notes and marginal notations. The other set may have been a more general office file, but it also contains meeting notes by Monica Neal (who kept the minutes). In addition to the board packets and memos, this series also contains various financial and statistical reports. This set of files, which we attribute to Monica Neal, ends with the April 2006 meeting (Monica Neal left J.P. Morgan and the Taconic Foundation in the summer of 2006).

There was also a third set of board meeting files, for the period 1997–2004. These files appear to have been a set of office files, housed in ring binders, and possibly maintained by Hildy Simmons, though a few files include materials with notations by Monica Neal. For the most part this series contained unmarked copies of board meeting materials and memoranda, all of which duplicated material in the other files. Unique items (e.g., check request letters, copies of minutes) and or items with notations have been removed and integrated with the combined set of board materials.

In integrating these three sets of files, we have tried to maintain some distinction between materials from the separate sets of files, even as we have generally discarded duplicate materials. In most cases, we have used Lisa Philp's files as the base set of files, because they cover the broadest time range, and we have added the materials from Monica Neal's files to them, using a blank sheet of paper to separate the two sections. We have generally not noted the small amount of material added from the third set of files.

There is only one set of board files for the period September 2006–2009. These materials were filed with and continue Lisa Philp's set of files; they consist mainly of the meeting booklets, with very few notations.
Materials from 2010–2012 are from Casey Burgess Casteneda's files, but they include some notations by Lisa Philp, who served through May 2011.

As far as possible digital and analog files have been integrated in their arrangement and description. Electronic Meetings Materials from May 2009 to December 2012 and various Meeting Notes for 2003–2007 are integrated in the Meeting Materials and Notes files. Because the digital board files tend to be sorted by document type, we have retained this arrangement for the Agendas, Dockets, and Memos.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Files include board meeting booklets, supplemental materials, memoranda, and minutes, as well as notes and marginalia. Monica Neal served as meeting secretary from 1998 to April 2006.
Files for 2006–2009 consist primarily of the meeting booklets, with very few notes. Megan Watkins, Eve Rodsky, and Sara Rosen served as meeting secretaries during this period.

Materials for 2010–2012 appear to be from Casey Burgess's files. They include some interleaved material, highlighting, and marginal notes. Casey Burgess Casteneda served as meeting secretary from 2010 to 2013.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Organization Records series contains materials relating to the Currier Family, the history and administration of the Taconic Foundation, and the Taconic Foundation trustees.

There are few or no personal records for Stephen and Audrey Currier. Apart from a few files relating to the Currier children, the Currier Family files mainly concern memorial arrangements for Stephen and Audrey Currier following their disappearance in January 1967. The Memorial Book files include reminiscences of the Curriers gathered from friends and associates, and these tributes provide additional detail on the Curriers. There is one file of addresses Stephen Currier gave in 1966–1967 as president of Urban America. A card file recording the Curriers' personal giving from 1958 to 1967 is another significant source, and it should provide some insight into the distinctions and overlap between the Curriers' personal philanthropy and that of the Taconic Foundation particularly in its early years.

The Organization Records series mainly documents the Foundation's history and administration. It includes a second card file (Grants Index), which records Taconic Foundation grantmaking from 1958 to around 1997. For Taconic's main grantees, the cards provide a detailed summary of their grant history. The cards also provide useful access to grant information in cases where grant files are lacking or there are variant names.

Documents include reviews and reflective reports on the Foundation's past and future directions. Several files (including many of the Grantmaking files) reflect efforts to compile source material for a planned history of the Taconic Foundation. A significant proportion of the material pertains to the Foundation's transition to management by J.P. Morgan in 1997, and its efforts in the mid- to late-1990s to define its future course and then to accomplish its final spend down in the period 2008 – 2013.The Research by Staff files contain a series of position papers and program reviews, mostly created in 1998–1999. Research supported by Taconic includes papers on affordable housing coops by Susan Saegert, New Markets Tax Credits by P. Jefferson Armistead, and a 1989 evaluation of youth employment programs by Marc Freedman. Files relating to the Smokey House Project in Danby, Vermont, are found in this series rather than in the Grants series, reflecting, perhaps, its unique connection to the Foundation. Administrative files consist primarily of various financial records.

The files relating to the Trustees are uneven and provide only limited documentation of their work with the Foundation. There are sustained correspondence files for some trustees, such as Susan Curnan or Lloyd Garrison, but in most cases the Trustees files present only a partial and often insignificant record.

The series includes both paper and digital records. While there may be some duplication between the two formats, there is no exact correspondence between the paper and digital components of hybrid files, and the file contents do not necessarily coincide.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The Grants Index was originally composed of two sets of cards, both arranged alphabetically. At some point, probably in the 1970s, the Foundation created a new set of cards, and retyped the information from the older cards onto the new ones. The new cards tended to condense some of the information on the old cards and focused particularly on the grant actions and payments. Subsequent grants were recorded primarily on the new set of cards. The second set of cards was about twice as large as the first set.

We have integrated the two sets of cards in processing, because they are not an exact match and they complement each other. Some older cards were already interfiled in the newer file. In other cases, the older cards contain information not carried over to the new cards. When two cards are simple duplicates, we have retained only copy. When the cards contain additional information, there may be duplicate sets in the file.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Harold Fleming joined and directed the Southern Regional Council from around 1947 to the early 1960s. In 1961, at Stephen Currier's urging, he established the Potomac Institute, which he headed as executive director and later president and president emeritus until his death in 1992. He was also a trustee of the Taconic Foundation. Later materials concern his memorial and the posthumous publication of his manuscript history, The Potomac Chronicle.
